moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 c5: This was a somewhat premature push for the center, and so I reacted how I normally would in this position, with 5.cxd5.
moves.7... Nc6 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. a3 Bb6: I believe Black was either anticipating 10. b4 with this move or preparing to prompt the exchange of queens with 10...Qc5.
moves.14. Nxe5: He definitely should have taken the knight before doing this.
moves.21. Rd7+ Kh8: Another option is Rf7, but that would lead to 22. Rxf7 Kxf7 23. Nxb6! which for me would win a pawn and rook minus a knight, instead of just a bishop.
moves.22. Rxc7 Bxe4 23. Nd6: My peices move ever closer to the attack.
moves.23... Bd3 24. Nf7+ Rxf7: Probably the least problematic approach for black.
moves.25. Rxf7 f5: An unneeded pawn push in an attempt to save the f pawn. Better would have been g5, since after the rook takes f6 at least the king can come to g7.
moves.26. Bh6 Rg8 27. Rxa7 e4: Another unnecessary pawn push leaves my opponent helpless. He didn't even see the discovered attack on his rook.
moves.28. Bxg8 Kxg8 29. Rg7+ Kh8: At least Black would have had some time bought if Kf8.
moves.30. Rf7 Kg8 31. Rf8#: After a long day, I finish 2-0. It was a victory to be proud of, considering I did not at the time know my own strengh. Round three started the following morning.
